No thats exactly it. The problem is the average league player *does not learn to look at roles like that*, but thats due to the game not teaching its players to look at roles subjectively and versatile unlike say Dota for example where heroes are NOT restricted to any lane or particular role. "Play what works on its own instead of making something work". I remember i was flamed to HELL and back when i wanted to play Amumu support and i did well with it--a tanky initiator support such as nautilus or leona. People STILL didn't care because it wasn't the real leona or nautilus and their argument is always  "Why not just pick [standard support]?" And i wasn't messing around either; I was playing a serious support game.

Ive played games with an Ekko as my support and thought "Wow holy shit ekko support is great, why dont people play it more?" and Jhin support is AMAZING. In fact the amount of CC and initiation Jhin has im surprised he isnt already a standard support pick. The only difference is that hes a AD caster instead of an AP. (Brand, Annie)

League of legends tells the average player to let the meta play the game for them rather than the other way around. Ive always said this since i started playing 4 years ago and its still as evident today. People that will suddenly start playing MF support from this ember will only prove that. Just like when riot used to do Dark Horse articles and turned Brand into a support, and urgot into a mid. Imagine trying to do that BEFORE then? Imagine trying to play MF support before this game that made everyone go "Ohhhh ok it was in the LCS that means it ok right?"

But conversely youll see the kind of people that will be playing Teemo support or Xerath support or anything off meta in general BECAUSE they want to fuck around and they don't actually know what theyre doing at all, which gives a bad outlook on the people that actually ARE legitimately trying with something "off meta" so i CAN understand why people would be apprehensive not seeing standard because too many people have given off meta a troll reputation.

Yeah, as someone who has had more success on off-meta supports (ekko, maokai, and more recently leblanc) I actually find the whole argument of "what is a support" to be rather hilarious. For me, supports are a lot like food: there is plenty of different kinds of it and people will be constantly disagreeing on what is and isn't it. The fact some people have the audacity to bitch and moan when I choose to eat a bowl of curry-flavored cheerios when they themselves have probably eaten/done way worse makes me enjoy playing off-meta stuff even more, as I'm essentially experiencing a joy that they never will.

In a broader sense though, supports "have" to do one of these things to be viable:
-have a way to cc an enemy to make it easier for teammates to kill (pose defensive "kill threat")
-have a way to sustain allies whether it be through the use of heals/shields (pose defensive "anti-kill threat" )
-have a way to chunk out enemy laners putting them within "kill range" of your adc or forcing them to burn sustain/back more often (pose offensive "kill threat" )
-have a way to neutralize enemy heals/shields/defensive stats (pose offensive "anti-kill threat" )

If a support cannot do any of those 4 things, only then are they "unviable".

I once laned with a Xin Zhao support. We had someone screw up in the picks, and this guy said he would take support instead of jungle.

Now, I wouldn't consider myself a meta slave, but as long as your champ fits the standard requirements of the role you chose, then I won't argue it (even things like Lulu top, Malz jungle, or Vel'koz support). That said, Xin Zhao doesn't exactly have what it takes to be a common support.........unless you know what you're doing.

Not only did we win the game with this Xin support, we also dominated the lane. This Xin had full control over the bushes, and was very familiar with the limits of his champ. Since I'm an ADC that tries to capitalize on anything my support can do in lane, the Xin knockup did wonders.

And so, to this day, whenever someone goes "off meta", I just roll with it, and even kind of defend anyone going off meta because of this one player. Yeah, I might still get salty, and say "This is why you don't go (champ/role)". But, I don't shoot them down in champ select.

That's true, but the level of understanding about the game has to equal the zaniness of your pick. And it certainly helps if the ADC knows what to expect, too. 

THAT'S the biggest reason that people don't like off-meta picks. They have a hard time adapting to them and knowing what to do. Even if you play it perfectly, League is a team game. If your team doesn't know what's coming, it's hard to win sometimes. You can always get those steamroll games where it really doesn't matter because you are so far ahead, but the meta is established by the close games, not the steamroll ones.

Overall it's about the team comp. In bot lane, an adc doesn't really factor into the start of a fight unless they lane their CC. Cait has traps which are easily avoidable. So she's out. After 6, when MF, and Ashe both ult, Cait has nothing. Zyra is the damage dealer in the lane. Her strength comes from the fact that people tend to not focus her because she's "just the support" and that allows her to win. ROX made an effort to focus Zyra. An adc mid-early game does p much nothing without their support.

The MF and Ashe lane is very weak pre 6 and that is Zyra's time to bully them out. Combined with a jungle with some decent engage, that lane is dead. SKT's issue was that Olaf has no hard CC to help his bot lane out. Tbh I'm surprised SKT still picked Olaf even after ROX first picked Ashe. The MF and Ashe lane is also weak when being engaged upon. Notice they are very strong if they were the ones to start the fight. 

Anyway, people are going to find very quick that supp MF won't work in solo q  against a Zyra. Majority of players don't understand why it worked for ROX.
It worked because MF outranges Zyra and can safely land a kill without going into Zyra's ult range. Not much more else to it.
